CreateActivity.name: CreateActivity
CreateActivity.documentation:
Creates an activity. An activity is a task that you write in any programming language and host on any machine that has access to AWS Step Functions. Activities must poll Step Functions using the GetActivityTask API action and respond using SendTask* API actions. This function lets Step Functions know the existence of your activity and returns an identifier for use in a state machine and when polling from the activity.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

CreateActivity is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateActivity's idempotency check is based on the activity name. If a following request has different tags values, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, tags will not be updated, even if they are different.

CreateStateMachine.name: CreateStateMachine
CreateStateMachine.documentation:
Creates a state machine. A state machine consists of a collection of states that can do work (Task states), determine to which states to transition next (Choice states), stop an execution with an error (Fail states), and so on. State machines are specified using a JSON-based, structured language.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

CreateStateMachine is an idempotent API. Subsequent requests won’t create a duplicate resource if it was already created. CreateStateMachine's idempotency check is based on the state machine name and definition. If a following request has a different roleArn or tags, Step Functions will ignore these differences and treat it as an idempotent request of the previous. In this case, roleArn and tags will not be updated, even if they are different.

DeleteStateMachine.name: DeleteStateMachine
DeleteStateMachine.documentation:
Deletes a state machine. This is an asynchronous operation: It sets the state machine's status to DELETING and begins the deletion process. Each state machine execution is deleted the next time it makes a state transition.

The state machine itself is deleted after all executions are completed or deleted.

DescribeActivity.name: DescribeActivity
DescribeActivity.documentation:
Describes an activity.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

DescribeExecution.name: DescribeExecution
DescribeExecution.documentation:
Describes an execution.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

DescribeStateMachine.name: DescribeStateMachine
DescribeStateMachine.documentation:
Describes a state machine.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

DescribeStateMachineForExecution.name: DescribeStateMachineForExecution
DescribeStateMachineForExecution.documentation:
Describes the state machine associated with a specific execution.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

GetActivityTask.name: GetActivityTask
GetActivityTask.documentation:
Used by workers to retrieve a task (with the specified activity ARN) which has been scheduled for execution by a running state machine. This initiates a long poll, where the service holds the HTTP connection open and responds as soon as a task becomes available (i.e. an execution of a task of this type is needed.) The maximum time the service holds on to the request before responding is 60 seconds. If no task is available within 60 seconds, the poll returns a taskToken with a null string.

Workers should set their client side socket timeout to at least 65 seconds (5 seconds higher than the maximum time the service may hold the poll request).

Polling with GetActivityTask can cause latency in some implementations. See Avoid Latency When Polling for Activity Tasks in the Step Functions Developer Guide.

GetExecutionHistory.name: GetExecutionHistory
GetExecutionHistory.documentation:
Returns the history of the specified execution as a list of events. By default, the results are returned in ascending order of the timeStamp of the events. Use the reverseOrder parameter to get the latest events first.

If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

ListActivities.name: ListActivities
ListActivities.documentation:
Lists the existing activities.

If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

ListExecutions.name: ListExecutions
ListExecutions.documentation:
Lists the executions of a state machine that meet the filtering criteria. Results are sorted by time, with the most recent execution first.

If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

ListStateMachines.name: ListStateMachines
ListStateMachines.documentation:
Lists the existing state machines.

If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

This operation is eventually consistent. The results are best effort and may not reflect very recent updates and changes.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation:
List tags for a given resource.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

SendTaskFailure.name: SendTaskFailure
SendTaskFailure.documentation: Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report that the task identified by the taskToken failed.

SendTaskHeartbeat.name: SendTaskHeartbeat
SendTaskHeartbeat.documentation:
Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report to Step Functions that the task represented by the specified taskToken is still making progress. This action resets the Heartbeat clock. The Heartbeat threshold is specified in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition (HeartbeatSeconds). This action does not in itself create an event in the execution history. However, if the task times out, the execution history contains an ActivityTimedOut entry for activities, or a TaskTimedOut entry for for tasks using the job run or callback pattern.

The Timeout of a task, defined in the state machine's Amazon States Language definition, is its maximum allowed duration, regardless of the number of SendTaskHeartbeat requests received. Use HeartbeatSeconds to configure the timeout interval for heartbeats.

SendTaskSuccess.name: SendTaskSuccess
SendTaskSuccess.documentation: Used by activity workers and task states using the callback pattern to report that the task identified by the taskToken completed successfully.

StartExecution.name: StartExecution
StartExecution.documentation:
Starts a state machine execution.

StartExecution is idempotent. If StartExecution is called with the same name and input as a running execution, the call will succeed and return the same response as the original request. If the execution is closed or if the input is different, it will return a 400 ExecutionAlreadyExists error. Names can be reused after 90 days.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation:
Add a tag to a Step Functions resource.

An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: Remove a tag from a Step Functions resource

UpdateStateMachine.name: UpdateStateMachine
UpdateStateMachine.documentation:
Updates an existing state machine by modifying its definition and/or roleArn. Running executions will continue to use the previous definition and roleArn. You must include at least one of definition or roleArn or you will receive a MissingRequiredParameter error.

All StartExecution calls within a few seconds will use the updated definition and roleArn. Executions started immediately after calling UpdateStateMachine may use the previous state machine definition and roleArn.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

ActivityFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity that failed during an execution.

ActivityLimitExceeded.documentation: The maximum number of activities has been reached. Existing activities must be deleted before a new activity can be created.

activityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the activity.

name.documentation:
The name of the activity.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

ActivityScheduleFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity schedule failure that occurred during an execution.

resource.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scheduled activity.

input.documentation: The JSON data input to the activity task.

timeoutInSeconds.documentation: The maximum allowed duration of the activity task.

heartbeatInSeconds.documentation: The maximum allowed duration between two heartbeats for the activity task.

ActivityScheduledEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity scheduled during an execution.

workerName.documentation: The name of the worker that the task is assigned to. These names are provided by the workers when calling GetActivityTask.

ActivityStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the start of an activity during an execution.

output.documentation: The JSON data output by the activity task.

ActivitySucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity that successfully terminated during an execution.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the timeout.

ActivityTimedOutEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity timeout that occurred during an execution.

ActivityWorkerLimitExceeded.documentation: The maximum number of workers concurrently polling for activity tasks has been reached.

name.documentation:
The name of the activity to create. This name must be unique for your AWS account and region for 90 days. For more information, see Limits Related to State Machine Executions in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

tags.documentation:
The list of tags to add to a resource.

An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

activityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the created activity.

name.documentation:
The name of the state machine.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

definition.documentation: The Amazon States Language definition of the state machine. See Amazon States Language.

roleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role to use for this state machine.

tags.documentation:
Tags to be added when creating a state machine.

An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the created state machine.

creationDate.documentation: The date the state machine is created.

activityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the activity to delete.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the state machine to delete.

activityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the activity to describe.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the activity.

name.documentation:
The name of the activity.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution to describe.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the execution.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the executed stated machine.

name.documentation:
The name of the execution.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

stopDate.documentation: If the execution has already ended, the date the execution stopped.

input.documentation: The string that contains the JSON input data of the execution.

output.documentation:
The JSON output data of the execution.

This field is set only if the execution succeeds. If the execution fails, this field is null.

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution you want state machine information for.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the state machine associated with the execution.

name.documentation: The name of the state machine associated with the execution.

definition.documentation: The Amazon States Language definition of the state machine. See Amazon States Language.

roleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role of the State Machine for the execution.

updateDate.documentation: The date and time the state machine associated with an execution was updated. For a newly created state machine, this is the creation date.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the state machine to describe.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the state machine.

name.documentation:
The name of the state machine.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

status.documentation: The current status of the state machine.

definition.documentation: The Amazon States Language definition of the state machine. See Amazon States Language.

roleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role used when creating this state machine. (The IAM role maintains security by granting Step Functions access to AWS resources.)

creationDate.documentation: The date the state machine is created.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

ExecutionAbortedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an abort of an execution.

ExecutionAlreadyExists.documentation:
The execution has the same name as another execution (but a different input).

Executions with the same name and input are considered idempotent.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

ExecutionFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an execution failure event.

ExecutionLimitExceeded.documentation: The maximum number of running executions has been reached. Running executions must end or be stopped before a new execution can be started.

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the execution.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the executed state machine.

name.documentation:
The name of the execution.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

stopDate.documentation: If the execution already ended, the date the execution stopped.

input.documentation: The JSON data input to the execution.

roleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role used for executing AWS Lambda tasks.

ExecutionStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the start of the execution.

output.documentation: The JSON data output by the execution.

ExecutionSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the successful termination of the execution.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the timeout.

ExecutionTimedOutEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the execution timeout that occurred during the execution.

activityArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the activity to retrieve tasks from (assigned when you create the task using CreateActivity.)

workerName.documentation: You can provide an arbitrary name in order to identify the worker that the task is assigned to. This name is used when it is logged in the execution history.

taskToken.documentation: A token that identifies the scheduled task. This token must be copied and included in subsequent calls to SendTaskHeartbeat, SendTaskSuccess or SendTaskFailure in order to report the progress or completion of the task.

input.documentation: The string that contains the JSON input data for the task.

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution.

maxResults.documentation:
The maximum number of results that are returned per call. You can use nextToken to obtain further pages of results. The default is 100 and the maximum allowed page size is 1000. A value of 0 uses the default.

This is only an upper limit. The actual number of results returned per call might be fewer than the specified maximum.

reverseOrder.documentation: Lists events in descending order of their timeStamp.

nextToken.documentation: If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

events.documentation: The list of events that occurred in the execution.

nextToken.documentation: If nextToken is returned, there are more results available. The value of nextToken is a unique pagination token for each page. Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

timestamp.documentation: The date and time the event occurred.

id.documentation: The id of the event. Events are numbered sequentially, starting at one.

activityScheduleFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an activity schedule event that failed during an execution.

taskFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the failure of a task.

taskScheduledEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that was scheduled.

taskStartFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that failed to start.

taskStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that was started.

taskSubmitFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that where the submit failed.

taskSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that succeeded.

taskTimedOutEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that timed out.

mapStateStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about Map state that was started.

mapIterationStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an iteration of a Map state that was started.

mapIterationSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an iteration of a Map state that succeeded.

mapIterationFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an iteration of a Map state that failed.

mapIterationAbortedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an iteration of a Map state that was aborted.

lambdaFunctionStartFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function that failed to start during an execution.

lambdaFunctionSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function that terminated successfully during an execution.

HistoryEvent.documentation: Contains details about the events of an execution.

HistoryEventList.documentation: Contains details about the events that occurred during an execution.

InvalidArn.documentation: The provided Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is invalid.

InvalidDefinition.documentation: The provided Amazon States Language definition is invalid.

InvalidExecutionInput.documentation: The provided JSON input data is invalid.

InvalidOutput.documentation: The provided JSON output data is invalid.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

LambdaFunctionFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function that failed during an execution.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

LambdaFunctionScheduleFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a failed lambda function schedule event that occurred during an execution.

resource.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scheduled lambda function.

input.documentation: The JSON data input to the lambda function.

timeoutInSeconds.documentation: The maximum allowed duration of the lambda function.

LambdaFunctionScheduledEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function scheduled during an execution.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

LambdaFunctionStartFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function that failed to start during an execution.

output.documentation: The JSON data output by the lambda function.

LambdaFunctionSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function that successfully terminated during an execution.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the timeout.

LambdaFunctionTimedOutEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a lambda function timeout that occurred during an execution.

The maximum number of results that are returned per call. You can use nextToken to obtain further pages of results. The default is 100 and the maximum allowed page size is 1000. A value of 0 uses the default.

This is only an upper limit. The actual number of results returned per call might be fewer than the specified maximum.

Make the call again using the returned token to retrieve the next page. Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

Keep all other arguments unchanged. Each pagination token expires after 24 hours. Using an expired pagination token will return an HTTP 400 InvalidToken error.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Step Functions state machine or activity.

tags.documentation: An array of tags associated with the resource.

name.documentation: The name of the iteration’s parent Map state.

index.documentation: The index of the array belonging to the Map state iteration.

MapIterationEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an iteration of a Map state.

length.documentation: The size of the array for Map state iterations.

MapStateStartedEventDetails.documentation: Details about a Map state that was started.

MissingRequiredParameter.documentation: Request is missing a required parameter. This error occurs if both definition and roleArn are not specified.

ResourceNotFound.documentation: Could not find the referenced resource. Only state machine and activity ARNs are supported.

taskToken.documentation: The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by Step Functions when tasks are assigned to a worker, or in the context object when a workflow enters a task state. See GetActivityTaskOutput$taskToken.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

taskToken.documentation: The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by Step Functions when tasks are assigned to a worker, or in the context object when a workflow enters a task state. See GetActivityTaskOutput$taskToken.

The token that represents this task. Task tokens are generated by Step Functions when tasks are assigned to a worker, or in the context object when a workflow enters a task state. See GetActivityTaskOutput$taskToken.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the state machine to execute.

name.documentation:
The name of the execution. This name must be unique for your AWS account, region, and state machine for 90 days. For more information, see Limits Related to State Machine Executions in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

input.documentation:
The string that contains the JSON input data for the execution, for example:

"input": "{\"first_name\" : \"test\"}"

If you don't include any JSON input data, you still must include the two braces, for example: "input": "{}"

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the execution.

input.documentation: The string that contains the JSON input data for the state.

StateEnteredEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a state entered during an execution.

name.documentation:
The name of the state.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

output.documentation: The JSON output data of the state.

StateExitedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about an exit from a state during an execution.

StateMachineAlreadyExists.documentation: A state machine with the same name but a different definition or role ARN already exists.

StateMachineDeleting.documentation: The specified state machine is being deleted.

StateMachineDoesNotExist.documentation: The specified state machine does not exist.

StateMachineLimitExceeded.documentation: The maximum number of state machines has been reached. Existing state machines must be deleted before a new state machine can be created.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that identifies the state machine.

name.documentation:
The name of the state machine.

A name must not contain:

  • white space

  • brackets < > { } [ ]

  • wildcard characters ? *

  • special characters " # % \ ^ | ~ ` $ & , ; : /

  • control characters (U+0000-001F, U+007F-009F)

creationDate.documentation: The date the state machine is created.

executionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the execution to stop.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

Tag.documentation:
Tags are key-value pairs that can be associated with Step Functions state machines and activities.

An array of key-value pairs. For more information, see Using Cost Allocation Tags in the AWS Billing and Cost Management User Guide, and Controlling Access Using IAM Tags.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Step Functions state machine or activity.

tags.documentation:
The list of tags to add to a resource.

Tags may only contain Unicode letters, digits, white space, or these symbols: _ . : / = + - @.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

TaskFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task failure event.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

parameters.documentation: The JSON data passed to the resource referenced in a task state.

timeoutInSeconds.documentation: The maximum allowed duration of the task.

TaskScheduledEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task scheduled during an execution.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

TaskStartFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that failed to start during an execution.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

TaskStartedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the start of a task during an execution.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

TaskSubmitFailedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task that failed to submit during an execution.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

output.documentation: The response from a resource when a task has started.

TaskSubmittedEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a task submitted to a resource .

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

output.documentation: The full JSON response from a resource when a task has succeeded. This response becomes the output of the related task.

TaskSucceededEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about the successful completion of a task state.

resourceType.documentation: The action of the resource called by a task state.

resource.documentation: The service name of the resource in a task state.

cause.documentation: A more detailed explanation of the cause of the failure.

TaskTimedOutEventDetails.documentation: Contains details about a resource timeout that occurred during an execution.

TooManyTags.documentation: You've exceeded the number of tags allowed for a resource. See the Limits Topic in the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Step Functions state machine or activity.

tagKeys.documentation: The list of tags to remove from the resource.

stateMachineArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the state machine.

definition.documentation: The Amazon States Language definition of the state machine. See Amazon States Language.

roleArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role of the state machine.

updateDate.documentation: The date and time the state machine was updated.

documentation:
AWS Step Functions

AWS Step Functions is a service that lets you coordinate the components of distributed applications and microservices using visual workflows.

You can use Step Functions to build applications from individual components, each of which performs a discrete function, or task, allowing you to scale and change applications quickly. Step Functions provides a console that helps visualize the components of your application as a series of steps. Step Functions automatically triggers and tracks each step, and retries steps when there are errors, so your application executes predictably and in the right order every time. Step Functions logs the state of each step, so you can quickly diagnose and debug any issues.

Step Functions manages operations and underlying infrastructure to ensure your application is available at any scale. You can run tasks on AWS, your own servers, or any system that has access to AWS. You can access and use Step Functions using the console, the AWS SDKs, or an HTTP API. For more information about Step Functions, see the AWS Step Functions Developer Guide .
